apiClassifier.shortdesc: The enumeration class that defines the acceptable values for string case.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
The enumeration class that defines the acceptable values for string case.
This is a type-safe enumeration class, which means there is no possibility of creating instances externally. All acceptable values will be created automaticaly by this class internaly, through its constants.

apiConstructor.shortdesc: Constructor, creates a new StringCase object.

apiException.apiDesc: If there is an attempt to instantiation outside the internal code of this class. All acceptable values will be created automaticaly by this class internaly, through the constants. There's no possibility to use this constructor externally.

apiParam.apiDesc: The name of this enumeration constant.
The ordinal of this enumeration constant, that is its position in the enum declaration (where the initial constant is assigned an ordinal of zero).

apiConstructorDetail.apiDesc: Constructor, creates a new StringCase object.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that any logic performed against a given String should ignore its case.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that any logic performed against a given String should ignore its case.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that any logic performed against a given String should consider its case.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that any logic performed against a given String should consider its case.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface defines that a class can evaluate equality of instances.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This interface defines that a class can evaluate equality of instances.
A class that implements this interface provides an arbitrary evaluation of equality with another object.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Performs an arbitrary, specific evaluation of equality between this object and the other object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: true if the arbitrary evaluation considers the objects equal.

apiParam.apiDesc: The object to be compared for equality.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Performs an arbitrary, specific evaluation of equality between this object and the other object.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: A class that implements this interface indicates that it can be sorted by the sort() method.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
A class that implements this interface indicates that it can be sorted by the sort() method.
Usually the classes that implement this interface are collections of some sort.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Sorts the objects within this class.

apiReturn.apiDesc:
The return value depends on whether you pass any arguments, as described in the following list:
If you specify a value of 4 or Array.UNIQUESORT for the options argument and two or more elements being sorted have identical sort fields, returns a value of 0 and does not modify the array.
If you specify a value of 8 or Array.RETURNINDEXEDARRAY for the options parameter, an array is returned that reflects the results of the sort and the array is not modified.
Otherwise, nothing is returned and the array is modified to reflect the sort order.

apiParam.apiDesc: A comparison function used to determine the sorting order of elements in an array. For more info see IComparator.compare.

One or more numbers or defined constants, separated by the | (bitwise OR) operator, that change the behavior of the sort from the default. The following values are acceptable for options:
1 or Array.CASEINSENSITIVE
2 or Array.DESCENDING
4 or Array.UNIQUESORT
8 or Array.RETURNINDEXEDARRAY
16 or Array.NUMERIC

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc:
Sorts the objects within this class.
By default, Array.sort() works in the following way:
Sorting is case-sensitive (Z precedes a).
Sorting is ascending (a precedes b).
The array is modified to reflect the sort order; multiple elements that have identical sort fields are placed consecutively in the sorted array in no particular order.
All elements, regardless of data type, are sorted as if they were strings, so 100 precedes 99, because "1" is a lower string value than "9".

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the IComparator object to be used in the comparison.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the IComparator object to be used in the comparison.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the options to be used automatically to sort.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the options to be used automatically to sort.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: The enumeration class that defines the acceptable values for numeric rounding.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
The enumeration class that defines the acceptable values for numeric rounding.
This is a type-safe enumeration class, which means there is no possibility of creating instances externally. All acceptable values will be created automaticaly by this class internaly, through its constants.

apiConstructor.shortdesc: Constructor, creates a new NumericRounding object.

apiException.apiDesc: If there is an attempt to instantiation outside the internal code of this class. All acceptable values will be created automaticaly by this class internaly, through the constants. There's no possibility to use this constructor externally.

apiParam.apiDesc: The name of this enumeration constant.
The ordinal of this enumeration constant, that is its position in the enum declaration (where the initial constant is assigned an ordinal of zero).

apiConstructorDetail.apiDesc: Constructor, creates a new NumericRounding object.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded up.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded up.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded down.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded down.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should not be rounded.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should not be rounded.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded down or up, whichever is closer.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the constant that indicates that a numeric value should be rounded down or up, whichever is closer.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: Allows an object to control its own serialization.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc: Allows an object to control its own serialization.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Returns the source code String representation of the object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: The source code String representation of the object.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Returns the source code String representation of the object.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface imposes a total ordering on the objects of each class that implements it.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc: This interface imposes a total ordering on the objects of each class that implements it. This ordering is referred to as the class's natural ordering, and the class's compareTo method is referred to as its natural comparison method.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Compares this object with the specified object for order.

apiException.apiDesc: if the specified object's type prevents it from being compared to this object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Compares this object with the specified object for order.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: A class that implements this interface indicates that it can be cloned by the clone() method.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
A class that implements this interface indicates that it can be cloned by the clone() method.
The implementation of the clone() method should return a shallow copy of the object, copying every possible property.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Creates and return a shallow copy of the object.

apiException.apiDesc: If this object should not be cloned.

apiReturn.apiDesc: A new object that is a shallow copy of this instance.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Creates and return a shallow copy of the object.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface exposes a way to tell to an object that it is no longer needed.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This interface exposes a way to tell to an object that it is no longer needed.
When the dispose() method is invoked on an object, it should stop all its processes and kill all its references to another objects, explicitly controlling the lifecycle of all its dependencies. If the dependency also implements this interface, its dispose() method should be called by this object.
If the object has a parent class (base class) and the parent class also implements this interface, the dispose() method of the parent class should be called, propagating this action through the hierarchy of parents.
If the dispose() method is called more than once, the object should ignore all calls after the first one, without throwing an error.
Since the dispose() method was called, the object just wait to be released from memory by the garbage collection process.
The object should throw the org.as3coreaddendum.errors.ObjectDisposedError if some method is called after the dispose() method was called, indicating an illegal operation.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Dispose the object to be garbage collected.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Dispose the object to be garbage collected.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: A comparison function, which imposes a total ordering on some collection of objects.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc: A comparison function, which imposes a total ordering on some collection of objects.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Compares its two arguments for order.

apiReturn.apiDesc: A negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as the first argument is less than, equal to, or greater than the second.

apiParam.apiDesc: the first object to be compared.
the second object to be compared.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Compares its two arguments for order. Returns a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as the first argument is less than, equal to, or greater than the second.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface defines a contract for objects that contains an index.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This interface defines a contract for objects that contains an index.
It can be used, for example, by objects that can be found or sorted by its index.
If the object also implements flash.events.IEventDispatcher interface, it is highly recommended that the object dispatches org.as3coreaddendum.events.IndexEvent when its index setter is invoked.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the index of the object.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the index of the object.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This is the base class for implementation of enumeration objects.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This is the base class for implementation of enumeration objects.
This class shouldn't be instantiated directly, rather than enumeration classes must extend this class.
What is an Enumerated Type?
An Enumerated Type is a data type that consists of a pre-defined set of values. Each enumerator (constant) is a value. An Enumerated Type groups a set of interrelated logical values.
Actionscript 3.0 doesn't implements Enumerated types. Rather, its uses a class with only constants to define a set of interrelated logical values.
One example is the flash.display.StageAlign class. It is the set of logical values acceptable for the flash.display.Stage.align property.
But even without the support of Actionscript 3.0 for Enumerated types you can simulate this functionality extending this Enum class.
Why use an Enumerated Type rather than a class with constants?
Following the example above, if you open the Actionscript 3.0 Language Reference and quickly look at the class flash.display.Stage and see the align property, you will note that its type is String. So you cannot immediatly know what values you can assign to it. Only after discovering that there is a class flash.display.StageAlign you note that these are the acceptable values. So this is the first problem with this approach.
The second problem is that you really can assign any String to the align property. Nothing guarantees you will pass the values that are actually in the flash.display.StageAlign class. Nor will there be any error at compile time that say that something is wrong.
But if instead of using this approach was used Enumeration types, these two problems would become two good points.
First, looking at the Actionscript 3.0 Language Reference you would see that the property align is of the type StageAlign. Automatically you check this class and see how to use it to assign a value for the align property.
Even better, if you make a mistake the compiler will warn you. You will no longer able to send an invalid value for the property.
But even with this approach remains a problem to be solved. The client of your code can still create instances of your Enumerated Type and use them when needed. In most cases this is undesirable, because you have already defined the set of acceptable values through constants in its Enumerated Type.
To resolve this problem exists a solution: the type-safe enum pattern. It is described with an example at the end of the page.
You can also check the class NumericRounding listed in the section "See also" below.
So to summarize the benefits of using Enumerated types: they make your code (or API) more readable and safe.

example.p: Suppose that we have an API that make loading of files. The acceptable file types that the API can load can be defined by an Enumerated Type. In this example the name of the Enumerated Type will be FileType. Note that you don't need to use the suffix "Enum" in its name.
Then we define the types that the API can load. In this example the API can load just image, swf and mp3 files. So we have just three constants, one to each file type.

When we want to load a file, we use the appropriate constant to tell the API what type of file will be loaded. If you need a file type that doesn't exists in the Enumerated Type, this means that the API doesn't support that file type.

In the above example, if the user of the API need to load a file type that doesn't exists in the Enumerated Type, it could instantiate a new object FileType with the desired type, as in the example below:
example.codeblock:
import FileType;
var videoFileType:FileType = new FileType("Video", 3);
example.p: This behavior would be wrong, but still allowed by the technical point of view. This would create the illusion that the user can create new types at runtime and send them to the API.
To prevent this mistake, we can implement a pattern named type-safe enum. This pattern will prevents the user create new types, throwing a runtime error.
There are some ways to do this, we will see just one below:
What happens above is that when the FileType is loaded in the Flash Player memory at runtime, first all the static members are initialized. After that the static code block is executed:

So first all the constants are initialized with the FileType instances because the _created static variable is false and then immediately after that the _created is set to true. Thus no more instances can be created.
Your Enumerated Type is safe to be used only with the set of values pre-defined by you.

apiConstructor.shortdesc: Constructor, creates a new Enum object.

apiException.apiDesc: If the name argument is null or an empty String.
If this class is instantiated directly, in other words, if there is not another class extending this class.

apiParam.apiDesc: The name of this enumeration constant.
The ordinal of this enumeration constant, that is its position in the enum declaration (where the initial constant is assigned an ordinal of zero).

apiConstructorDetail.apiDesc: Constructor, creates a new Enum object.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Compares this enum with the specified object for order.

apiException.apiDesc: If the type of the argument o is other than this exactly enum type instance.

apiReturn.apiDesc: a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

apiParam.apiDesc: The target object to be compared.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc:
Compares this enum with the specified object for order.
Enum constants are only comparable to other enum constants of the same enum type. The natural order implemented by this method is the order in which the constants are declared.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Compares the target object for equality with this object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: true if the specified object is equal to this enum constant.

apiParam.apiDesc: The object to be compared for equality with this object.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Compares the target object for equality with this object.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Returns the source code String representation of the object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: The source code String representation of the object.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc: Returns the source code String representation of the object.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Returns the name of this enum constant, as contained in the declaration.

apiReturn.apiDesc: The name of this enum constant.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc:
Returns the name of this enum constant, as contained in the declaration.
This method may be overridden, though it typically isn't necessary or desirable. An enum type should override this method when a more "programmer-friendly" string form exists.

apiOperation.shortdesc: Returns the primitive value of the object.

apiReturn.apiDesc: The primitive value of the object. In this case, the ordinal value.

apiOperationDetail.apiDesc:
Returns the primitive value of the object.
This method is called automatically by the Flash Player every time an arithmetic operation occur. Thus, it's possible to perform these operations to check the position between two or more enum constants.

apiValue.shortdesc: The name of this enum constant exactly as supplied by the constructor.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc:
The name of this enum constant exactly as supplied by the constructor.
Most programmers should use the toString() method in preference to this one, as the toString() method may return a more user-friendly name. This property is designed primarily for use in specialized situations where correctness depends on getting the exact name.

apiValue.shortdesc: The ordinal of this enumeration constant (its position in its enum declaration, where the initial constant is assigned an ordinal of zero).

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: The ordinal of this enumeration constant (its position in its enum declaration, where the initial constant is assigned an ordinal of zero).

apiClassifier.shortdesc: Defines an interface to initialize the object.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
Defines an interface to initialize the object.
Classes that need to be initialized before being used can implement this interface to define an initialization pattern.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines if the object is initialized or not.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines if the object is initialized or not.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface defines a contract for objects that specify a type.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This interface defines a contract for objects that specify a type. A type can be anything, e.g. a Class, a Function, etc.
It can be used, for example, by collections that restrict the type of its elements.

apiClassifier.shortdesc: This interface defines a contract for objects that contains a priority.

apiClassifierDetail.apiDesc:
This interface defines a contract for objects that contains a priority.
If the object also implements flash.events.IEventDispatcher interface, it is highly recommended that the object dispatches org.as3coreaddendum.events.PriorityEvent when its priority setter is invoked.

apiValue.shortdesc: Defines the priority of the object.

apiValueDetail.apiDesc: Defines the priority of the object.
